text: Nikola Tesla had a photographic memory and could visualize entire machines in his head, building them mentally before ever touching a tool.
Darwin waited 20 years to publish On the Origin of Species because he knew how controversial it would be.
Isaac Newton invented calculus during quarantine when Cambridge closed due to the plague.
Einstein's brain was stolen during his autopsy and kept in jars for decades before being studied.
Marie Curie's notebooks are still so radioactive they're kept in lead-lined boxes and require protective equipment to handle.
The scientist who proposed hand-washing to prevent infection was ridiculed by the medical community and died in an insane asylum.
Galileo's middle finger is on display in a museum in Florence, Italy.
The last words of Einstein were in German, and the nurse who was with him didn't speak German, so they were lost forever.
Leonardo da Vinci wrote backwards in mirror script, possibly to keep his ideas secret or because he was left-handed.
The Antikythera mechanism, found in a 2,000-year-old shipwreck, is an ancient analog computer that predicted astronomical positions.
Werner Heisenberg, creator of the uncertainty principle, got a C in lab work because his experimental skills were poor.
Rosalind Franklin's X-ray crystallography work was crucial to discovering DNA's structure, but she died before the Nobel Prize was awarded.
Ancient Romans used urine to whiten their teeth — the ammonia in urine is actually an effective whitener.
Aristotle believed women had fewer teeth than men — he never bothered to count, despite having two wives.
The Big Bang theory was proposed by a Catholic priest, Georges Lemaître, and was initially rejected by Einstein.
Tycho Brahe lost his nose in a duel over a math formula and wore a metal prosthetic for the rest of his life.
Benjamin Franklin nearly electrocuted himself and was knocked unconscious while experimenting with electricity.
Carl Sagan applied to work at NASA but was rejected — he went on to become the most famous science communicator of his generation.
The scientist who discovered that atoms could be split initially thought his finding was useless.
Ancient Greeks knew the Earth was round and calculated its circumference with surprising accuracy over 2,000 years ago.
Einstein was offered the presidency of Israel but declined, saying he lacked the natural aptitude for dealing with people.
Mendeleev predicted the existence of elements that hadn't been discovered yet by leaving gaps in his periodic table.
The first computer programmer was Ada Lovelace, a woman, in the 1840s — over 100 years before modern computers.
Thomas Edison electrocuted an elephant named Topsy to prove the dangers of his rival Tesla's AC current.
Fleming's discovery of penicillin only happened because he was messy and left a petri dish uncovered while on vacation.
Nobel invented dynamite and created the Nobel Prize partly because he was upset by his own obituary calling him a 'merchant of death.'
Carl Linnaeus classified humans as 'Homo sapiens' (wise man) in 1758, but couldn't use a different name because of scientific naming rules he created himself.
Archimedes was killed by a Roman soldier while doing geometry in the sand — his last words were reportedly 'Do not disturb my circles.'
Darwin and Lincoln were born on the exact same day — February 12, 1809.
Schrödinger proposed his famous cat thought experiment to show how absurd quantum mechanics seemed, not to support it.
The word 'scientist' wasn't coined until 1833 — before that, scientists were called 'natural philosophers.'
Louis Pasteur was so afraid of germs that he refused to shake hands with people.
Copernicus's book proposing heliocentrism was only banned by the Catholic Church 73 years after publication.
The scientist who discovered oxygen, Joseph Priestley, died still believing in phlogiston theory.
Alan Turing, who helped crack the Nazi Enigma code and is considered the father of computer science, was chemically castrated for being gay.
Kepler's laws of planetary motion were derived from Tycho Brahe's astronomical data, which Kepler may have stolen.
The first successful vaccine was created by Edward Jenner using cowpox — the word 'vaccine' comes from 'vacca,' Latin for cow.
Pythagoras's followers kept his teachings secret and were sworn to silence — we know very little about what Pythagoras himself actually believed.
Robert Hooke and Isaac Newton were bitter rivals — Newton allegedly had Hooke's portrait destroyed after Hooke died.
Nikola Tesla claimed to have invented a 'death ray' but destroyed the plans before he died.
Dmitri Mendeleev reportedly came up with the periodic table arrangement in a dream.
The Mayans independently invented the concept of zero around the same time as Indian mathematicians, with no contact between the cultures.
Hippocrates, the 'father of medicine,' believed illness came from imbalances in four bodily humors — a theory that persisted for 2,000 years.
Marie Curie remains the only person to win Nobel Prizes in two different sciences: Physics and Chemistry.
The ancient Egyptians used moldy bread to treat infected wounds — accidentally discovering antibiotic properties.
Lavoisier, the father of modern chemistry, was executed during the French Revolution — the judge said 'The Republic needs neither scientists nor chemists.'
Feynman cracked safes at Los Alamos for fun during the Manhattan Project, causing security concerns.
Wernher von Braun designed rockets for Nazi Germany before becoming the architect of NASA's Apollo program.
The first atomic bomb test at Trinity was so bright that a blind woman 120 miles away asked 'What was that?'
Ancient Babylonians were doing trigonometry 1,000 years before the Greeks — clay tablets prove it.
